awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: RUI: Competitive Search, Evacuation and Reconfiguration with Coordinated Mobile Agents
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent years, innovations in special-purpose sensor hardware and machine-learning algorithms have led to rapid advances in robotics and autonomous vehicle technology. This project aims to develop and analyze algorithms for an ensemble of mobile agents working in parallel to achieve coordinated, goal-directed motion in simple geometric spaces that are abstractions of complex terrains. The agents cooperate among themselves to efficiently search, explore, synchronize and reconfigure into patterns using distributed algorithms with limited memory, sensing and communication capabilities. The research will contribute to a deeper understanding of coordination protocols to complete navigational tasks, even when some of the agents may be faulty. Results from the research will provide critical insights that can be used in robot-assisted applications such as search-and-rescue in hostile or unknown terrains, or surface exploration needed to develop and maintain future colonies and human outposts on other planets. The study of reconfiguration problems will also provide ideas that can shed light on previously unexplained aspects of flocking phenomena in birds, such as murmurations. The project will involve undergraduate students in theoretical research and will train them to develop and maintain an open-source repository of distributed algorithms for robot coordination problems and their animations. In addition, results from the project will be archived as a permanent online resource for the parallel and distributed computing community at large. Two specific annual initiatives for outreach will be a part of the project: firstly, participation by the investigator and undergraduate research students in the Rutgers Future Scholars program, and secondly, conducting workshops for K-12 teachers to teach basic computational and algorithm design skills.

The project addresses fundamental theoretical problems of efficient, coordinated exploration and reconfiguration by a team of mobile agents as they work together to accomplish a computational task in simple geometric spaces.  Three basic problem settings are considered: (a) the search problem, where an unknown target location, which can only be sensed when reached, has to be found by at least one robot in the team, (b) the evacuation problem, that requires some subset of the robots to reach an unknown exit location in the region after it has been found, and (c) the reconfiguration problem, where the robots must rearrange themselves in a certain desired configuration based on either a given arrangement or on local rules. Within each problem setting, the goal is to develop an algorithm for the robots so that they can attain the desired configuration or complete the task defined by the problem with the minimum amount of resource usage possible, e.g. total distance traveled or time taken. Many interesting variants of the problems will also be studied, such as the peculiarities of the region's geometry, constraints on the communication capabilities of the robots, and handling faulty robots that may be benign or malicious.

por.por_cntn:
This project involved a systematic study of several theoretical problems concerning search and exploration of a geometric or graph domain by a collection of mobile agents. Such problems are canonical in the distributed algorithms literature and the development and analysis of efficient algorithms for these problems can provide insights into the complexity of general-purpose search.

The agent model is quite versatile: agents can move with possibly different speeds, can have diverse communication capabilities, and may consume  energy as a function of speed and/or distance traveled. Typically, an unknown target point is being searched, and is only considered found when an agent reaches that point as it moves in the domain. Sometimes, the goal is to simply to find this point as fast as possible, and in other situations, the point is like an exit from which one or more of the agents need to evacuate. Ths, any algorithm in this setting is an online, distributed algorithm because there is no fore-knowledge of the target/exit and agents explore the domain using their own program without centralized control. 

The research results obtained in this project spanned several different kinds of search problem scenarios in which theoretical lower and upper bounds on search/evacuation time were derived. In most scenarios, the upper bounds on resource use (time, energy etc.) are characterized as a competitive ratio, withnthe algorithm competeing against an ideal offline algorithm with complete knowledge.  

Among the many results obtained in this research program were optimal or near-optimal algorithms for the following problems:

  • evacuation - from a unit disk - of one or more distinguished agents with priority over all other agents; 
  • evacuation - from an infinite line - of two agents where either total energy consumption is minimized, or when the evacuation time is minimized subject to a bound on available energy; 
  • fault-tolerant search - from an infinite line - when a fraction of the agents exhibit so-called Byzantine faults where an agent can maliciously lie about finding (or not finding) an exit; 
  • evacuation - from an infinite line - when agents have different communication capabilities such as being pure transmitters or pure receivers of messages from other agents; 
  • complete exploration of all edges of a finite graph by multiple agents with constraints on available energy. 

The PI's institution is designated as being primarily monority-serving. As part of the broader impact, the PI trained and closely mentored a group of undergraduate students - some of whom belong to historically under-represented groups in Computer Science - in research and technical skills. As a pedagogical tool for understanding some of the distributed algorithms conceived during the research program, students in the research team developed replayable, Javascript-based animations that clearly demonstrate the evolution of the search/evacuation in these algorithms. The students on the team also took part in helping the PI conduct Software Carpentry workshops, with two of the students even getting certified as instructors. 

The PI also designed and ran a week-long, intensive workshop for STEM high-school teachers on computational thinking, algorithm development, and problem-solving skills allied to coding and implementing algorithms. The workshop will now be a recurring, professional development activity that will be organized and conducted every summer for the Camden school district.
